newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgian demonstrators demand cannabis legalisation.
newsitem.headline: Belgian demonstrators demand cannabis legalisation.

text.p: Up to 2,000 mostly young Belgians demonstrated in central Brussels on Saturday to demand the legalisation of cannabis.
Demonstrators, some of them smoking cannabis cigarettes, carried banners advocating that the use of the drug be made legal.
"Cannabis is not prohibited because it is dangerous, it is dangerous because it is prohibited," one of the banners said.
Matthew, 19, complained he felt like an outlaw because the drug is illegal in Belgium while his parents could drink wine without any problems.
"I like to smoke a joint every weekend," he told Reuters, stressing, however, that the drug should be used in moderation.
Police estimated that between 1,500 and 2,000 people took part in the event, Belga news agency reported.

Last year, Belgian Interior Minister Johan Vande Lanotte, who admitted using drugs when he was younger, said he opposed legalising soft drugs, crushing a proposal by a parliamentarian to lift the ban.

Francophone socialist member of parliament Patrick Moriau, whose party is part of the centre-left government, has advocated legislation to legalise the use of soft drugs in Belgium. Moriau attended Saturday's demonstration, Belga said.
